title: The Resurrection
shortSummary: 1 Corinthians 15 presents a foundational teaching on the resurrection of Jesus Christ and the future resurrection of believers. Paul defends the reality and necessity of the resurrection, explaining its implications for Christian faith, hope, and victory over death. This chapter is crucial for understanding the gospel's power and the believer’s eternal hope.
timeline: c. AD 55 - Paul's Epistle to the Corinthians during his Third Missionary Journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle who authored this letter, defending the resurrection and explaining its theological significance.

keyCharacters.name: Cephas (Peter)
keyCharacters.description: One of the twelve apostles, mentioned as a primary witness to the risen Christ.

keyCharacters.name: James
keyCharacters.description: Brother of Jesus and leader in the Jerusalem church, who also saw the risen Christ.

keyCharacters.name: The Twelve Apostles
keyCharacters.description: The original disciples of Jesus who witnessed His resurrection and preached the gospel.

definitions.definition: The rising of Jesus Christ from the dead on the third day, and the future rising of believers to eternal life.
A term referring to Christ as the first to rise from the dead, guaranteeing the resurrection of believers.
A state of imperishability and immortality that believers will receive at the resurrection.
A practice mentioned by Paul, possibly referring to vicarious baptism, used here to argue for belief in resurrection.

outline.heading: The Gospel and Resurrection Witnesses
outline.description: Paul reminds the Corinthians of the gospel he preached, emphasizing Christ’s death, burial, resurrection, and appearances to many witnesses, establishing the historical foundation of the resurrection.

outline.heading: The Necessity of the Resurrection
outline.description: Paul argues that if there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ has not been raised, making Christian faith and preaching meaningless and leaving believers still in sin.

outline.heading: Christ the Firstfruits and the Order of Resurrection
outline.description: Christ’s resurrection is presented as the firstfruits of those who have died, with a future resurrection at His coming, culminating in the final defeat of all enemies including death.

outline.heading: Proofs and Practical Implications of Resurrection
outline.description: Paul uses practical arguments and warnings to affirm the resurrection’s reality and exhort the Corinthians to live righteously.

outline.heading: The Nature of the Resurrection Body
outline.description: Paul explains the transformation from the natural, perishable body to a spiritual, imperishable body, contrasting Adam and Christ as the first and last man.

outline.heading: The Mystery and Victory of the Resurrection
outline.description: Paul reveals the mystery of the resurrection transformation at Christ’s return, culminating in the victory over death and a call to steadfast service.

application: Stand firm in the gospel of Christ’s resurrection as the foundation of your faith and hope.
Live a life of holiness and righteousness, knowing that your labor in the Lord is never in vain.
Rejoice in the victory over death through Jesus Christ and let this hope strengthen you in trials.
Be steadfast and immovable in your service to God, motivated by the certainty of eternal life.

keyVerses.text: For I delivered unto you first of all that which I also received, how that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures; And that he was buried, and that he rose again the third day according to the scriptures:
keyVerses.significance: This verse summarizes the core gospel message and the historical reality of Christ’s death and resurrection.

keyVerses.text: And if Christ be not raised, your faith is vain; ye are yet in your sins.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the essential nature of the resurrection for the validity of Christian faith and forgiveness of sins.

keyVerses.text: But now is Christ risen from the dead, and become the firstfruits of them that slept.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms Christ as the first to rise, guaranteeing the future resurrection of believers.

keyVerses.text: But thanks be to God, which giveth us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
keyVerses.significance: It celebrates the victory over death and sin made possible through Jesus Christ.
